trans-unit.source: Azure Search Service REST API Version 2014-07-31-Preview
trans-unit.target: Azure Search Service REST API Version 2014-07-31-Preview

trans-unit.source: Azure Search Service REST API: Version 2014-07-31-Preview
trans-unit.target: Azure Search Service REST API: Version 2014-07-31-Preview

trans-unit.source: This document describes the older 2014-07-31-Preview version of the Azure Search Service REST API, released for the Azure Search Public Preview in August 2014.
trans-unit.target: This document describes the older 2014-07-31-Preview version of the Azure Search Service REST API, released for the Azure Search Public Preview in August 2014.

trans-unit.source: Because this version will be phased out soon, we strongly recommend that you use the version associated with the generally available release instead.
trans-unit.target: Because this version will be phased out soon, we strongly recommend that you use the version associated with the generally available release instead.

trans-unit.source: For guidance on code migration, see <linkText>Transition from preview to the generally available API version</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For guidance on code migration, see <linkText>Transition from preview to the generally available API version</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Other API content related to 2014-07-31-Preview includes the following:
trans-unit.target: Other API content related to 2014-07-31-Preview includes the following:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Scoring Profiles (Azure Search Service REST API: 2014-07-31-Preview)</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Scoring Profiles (Azure Search Service REST API: 2014-07-31-Preview)</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Documentation for the current, generally available version of the Azure Search REST API can be found on MSDN.
trans-unit.target: Documentation for the current, generally available version of the Azure Search REST API can be found on MSDN.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Azure Search Service REST API</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Azure Search Service REST API</linkText><title></title> for more information.

trans-unit.source: Azure Search is a cloud-based service that you can use to build custom search applications.
trans-unit.target: Azure Search is a cloud-based service that you can use to build custom search applications.

trans-unit.source: Azure Search has the concepts of search services and indexes, where a search service contains one or more indexes.
trans-unit.target: Azure Search has the concepts of search services and indexes, where a search service contains one or more indexes.

trans-unit.source: Your search service is uniquely identified by a fully-qualified domain name (for example: mysearchservice.search.windows.net).
trans-unit.target: Your search service is uniquely identified by a fully-qualified domain name (for example: mysearchservice.search.windows.net).

trans-unit.source: An api-key is generated when the service is provisioned, and is used to authenticate requests to your Azure Search service.
trans-unit.target: An api-key is generated when the service is provisioned, and is used to authenticate requests to your Azure Search service.

trans-unit.source: There are two types of actions that can be executed against the Azure Search Service:
trans-unit.target: There are two types of actions that can be executed against the Azure Search Service:

trans-unit.source: Index Management: This includes administrative tasks that are executed against a search service or search index.
trans-unit.target: Index Management: This includes administrative tasks that are executed against a search service or search index.

trans-unit.source: Document Actions: These actions query and manage the corpus for a given index.
trans-unit.target: Document Actions: These actions query and manage the corpus for a given index.

trans-unit.source: The APIs documented in this section provide access to operations on search data, such as index creation and population, document upload, and queries.
trans-unit.target: The APIs documented in this section provide access to operations on search data, such as index creation and population, document upload, and queries.

trans-unit.source: When calling the API, keep the following points in mind:
trans-unit.target: When calling the API, keep the following points in mind:

trans-unit.source: All APIs are defined in terms of HTTP requests and responses in OData JSON format.
trans-unit.target: All APIs are defined in terms of HTTP requests and responses in OData JSON format.

trans-unit.source: All APIs must be accompanied with an api-key in the header or in the query string as described in the notes below.
trans-unit.target: All APIs must be accompanied with an api-key in the header or in the query string as described in the notes below.

trans-unit.source: All APIs must be issued over HTTPS (on the default port - 443).
trans-unit.target: All APIs must be issued over HTTPS (on the default port - 443).

trans-unit.source: All API requests must include the api-version query string parameter.
trans-unit.target: All API requests must include the api-version query string parameter.

trans-unit.source: Its value must be set to the version of the current service release, which is shown in the following example:
trans-unit.target: Its value must be set to the version of the current service release, which is shown in the following example:

trans-unit.source: GET /indexes?api-version=2014-07-31-Preview
trans-unit.target: GET /indexes?api-version=2014-07-31-Preview

trans-unit.source: All API requests can optionally set the Accept HTTP header.
trans-unit.target: All API requests can optionally set the Accept HTTP header.

trans-unit.source: If unset, the default is assumed to be application/json.
trans-unit.target: If unset, the default is assumed to be application/json.

trans-unit.source: A separate API is provided for service administration.
trans-unit.target: A separate API is provided for service administration.

trans-unit.source: Examples of service administration operations include provisioning the service or altering capacity.
trans-unit.target: Examples of service administration operations include provisioning the service or altering capacity.

trans-unit.source: For more information about this API, see Azure Search Management REST API.
trans-unit.target: For more information about this API, see Azure Search Management REST API.

trans-unit.source: The endpoint for service operations is the URL of the Azure Search service you provisioned: https://<yourService>.search.windows.net.
trans-unit.target: The endpoint for service operations is the URL of the Azure Search service you provisioned: https://<yourService>.search.windows.net.

trans-unit.source: There are multiple API versions for Azure Search.
trans-unit.target: There are multiple API versions for Azure Search.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Search Service Versioning</linkText><title></title> for a list of the available versions.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Search Service Versioning</linkText><title></title> for a list of the available versions.

trans-unit.source: Authentication to an Azure Search service requires two pieces of information: a search service URL, and an api-key.
trans-unit.target: Authentication to an Azure Search service requires two pieces of information: a search service URL, and an api-key.

trans-unit.source: The api-keys are generated when the service is created, and can be regenerated on demand after the service is provisioned.
trans-unit.target: The api-keys are generated when the service is created, and can be regenerated on demand after the service is provisioned.

trans-unit.source: An api-key is always one of the following:
trans-unit.target: An api-key is always one of the following:

trans-unit.source: an admin key that grants access to all operations, including write operations like creating and deleting indexes.
trans-unit.target: an admin key that grants access to all operations, including write operations like creating and deleting indexes.

trans-unit.source: a query key that authenticates read-only requests.
trans-unit.target: a query key that authenticates read-only requests.

trans-unit.source: You can have 2 admin keys and up to 50 query keys per service.
trans-unit.target: You can have 2 admin keys and up to 50 query keys per service.

trans-unit.source: Having 2 admin keys is helpful when you need to rollover one of the keys.
trans-unit.target: Having 2 admin keys is helpful when you need to rollover one of the keys.

trans-unit.source: Access control is limited to service administration via the role-based access controls (RBAC) provided in the Azure Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: Access control is limited to service administration via the role-based access controls (RBAC) provided in the Azure Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: Roles are used to set levels of access for service administration.
trans-unit.target: Roles are used to set levels of access for service administration.

trans-unit.source: For example, viewing the admin key is restricted to the Owner and Contributor roles, whereas viewing service status is visible to members of any role.
trans-unit.target: For example, viewing the admin key is restricted to the Owner and Contributor roles, whereas viewing service status is visible to members of any role.

trans-unit.source: Data operations performed against a Search service endpoint, including index management, index population, and queries, are accessed via api-keys exclusively.
trans-unit.target: Data operations performed against a Search service endpoint, including index management, index population, and queries, are accessed via api-keys exclusively.

trans-unit.source: RBAC does not apply to either index or document-related operations.
trans-unit.target: RBAC does not apply to either index or document-related operations.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about api-keys or RBAC in Azure Search, see Manage your Search service on Microsoft Azure.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about api-keys or RBAC in Azure Search, see Manage your Search service on Microsoft Azure.

trans-unit.source: Note: In general it is considered poor security practice to pass sensitive data such as api-key in the request URI.
trans-unit.target: Note: In general it is considered poor security practice to pass sensitive data such as api-key in the request URI.

trans-unit.source: For this reason, Azure Search will only accept a query key as an api-key in the query string, and you should avoid doing so unless the contents of your index should be publicly available.
trans-unit.target: For this reason, Azure Search will only accept a query key as an api-key in the query string, and you should avoid doing so unless the contents of your index should be publicly available.

trans-unit.source: Instead, we recommend passing your api-key as a request header.
trans-unit.target: Instead, we recommend passing your api-key as a request header.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Search Service API supports two syntaxes for entity lookup: <linkText>simple</linkText><title></title> and alternate OData syntax (see <linkText>Support for OData (Azure Search API)</linkText><title></title> for details).
trans-unit.target: The Azure Search Service API supports two syntaxes for entity lookup: <linkText>simple</linkText><title></title> and alternate OData syntax (see <linkText>Support for OData (Azure Search API)</linkText><title></title> for details).

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Delete an Index</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add, Delete, and Update Data within an Index</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: You can create and manage indexes in Azure Search service via simple HTTP requests (POST, GET, PUT, DELETE) against a given index resource.
trans-unit.target: You can create and manage indexes in Azure Search service via simple HTTP requests (POST, GET, PUT, DELETE) against a given index resource.

trans-unit.source: To create an index, you first POST a JSON document that describes the index schema.
trans-unit.target: To create an index, you first POST a JSON document that describes the index schema.

trans-unit.source: The schema defines the fields of the index, their data types, and how they can be used (for example, in full-text searches, filters, sorting, faceting, or suggestions).
trans-unit.target: The schema defines the fields of the index, their data types, and how they can be used (for example, in full-text searches, filters, sorting, faceting, or suggestions).

trans-unit.source: It also defines scoring profiles and other attributes to configure the behavior of the index.
trans-unit.target: It also defines scoring profiles and other attributes to configure the behavior of the index.

trans-unit.source: The following example provides an illustration of a schema used for searching on hotel information with the Description field defined in two languages.
trans-unit.target: The following example provides an illustration of a schema used for searching on hotel information with the Description field defined in two languages.

trans-unit.source: Notice how attributes control how the field is used.
trans-unit.target: Notice how attributes control how the field is used.

trans-unit.source: For example the hotelId is used as the document key ("key": true) and is excluded from full-text searches ("searchable": false).
trans-unit.target: For example the hotelId is used as the document key ("key": true) and is excluded from full-text searches ("searchable": false).

trans-unit.source: After the index is created, you'll upload documents that populate the index.
trans-unit.target: After the index is created, you'll upload documents that populate the index.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Add or Update Documents</linkText><title></title> for this next step.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Add or Update Documents</linkText><title></title> for this next step.

trans-unit.source: For a video introduction to indexing in Azure Search, see the <linkText>Channel 9 Cloud Cover episode on Azure Search</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For a video introduction to indexing in Azure Search, see the <linkText>Channel 9 Cloud Cover episode on Azure Search</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can create a new index within an Azure Search service using an HTTP POST request.
trans-unit.target: You can create a new index within an Azure Search service using an HTTP POST request.

trans-unit.source: The body of the request is a JSON document that specifies the index name, fields, attributes to control query behavior, scoring of results, and CORS options.
trans-unit.target: The body of the request is a JSON document that specifies the index name, fields, attributes to control query behavior, scoring of results, and CORS options.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can use PUT and specify the index name on the URI.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can use PUT and specify the index name on the URI.

trans-unit.source: If the index does not exist, it will be created.
trans-unit.target: If the index does not exist, it will be created.

trans-unit.source: Note: The maximum number of indexes allowed varies by pricing tier.
trans-unit.target: Note: The maximum number of indexes allowed varies by pricing tier.

trans-unit.source: The free service allows up to 3 indexes.
trans-unit.target: The free service allows up to 3 indexes.

trans-unit.source: Standard service allows 50 indexes per Search service.
trans-unit.target: Standard service allows 50 indexes per Search service.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Limits and constraints</linkText><title></title> for details.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Limits and constraints</linkText><title></title> for details.

trans-unit.source: Request
trans-unit.target: Request

trans-unit.source: HTTPS is required for all service requests.
trans-unit.target: HTTPS is required for all service requests.

trans-unit.source: The Create Index request can be constructed using either a POST or PUT method.
trans-unit.target: The Create Index request can be constructed using either a POST or PUT method.

trans-unit.source: When using POST, you must provide an index name in the request body along with the index schema definition.
trans-unit.target: When using POST, you must provide an index name in the request body along with the index schema definition.

trans-unit.source: With PUT, the index name is part of the URL.
trans-unit.target: With PUT, the index name is part of the URL.

trans-unit.source: If the index doesn't exist, it is created.
trans-unit.target: If the index doesn't exist, it is created.

trans-unit.source: If it already exists, it is updated to the new definition.
trans-unit.target: If it already exists, it is updated to the new definition.

trans-unit.source: The index name must be lower case, start with a letter or number, have no slashes or dots, and be less than 128 characters.
trans-unit.target: The index name must be lower case, start with a letter or number, have no slashes or dots, and be less than 128 characters.

trans-unit.source: After starting the index name with a letter or number, the rest of the name can include any letter, number and dashes, as long as the dashes are not consecutive.
trans-unit.target: After starting the index name with a letter or number, the rest of the name can include any letter, number and dashes, as long as the dashes are not consecutive.

trans-unit.source: The api-version is required.
trans-unit.target: The api-version is required.

trans-unit.source: Valid values include 2014-07-31-Preview or 2014-10-20-Preview.
trans-unit.target: Valid values include 2014-07-31-Preview or 2014-10-20-Preview.

trans-unit.source: You can specify which one to use on each request to get version-specific behaviors, but as a best practice, use the same version throughout your code.
trans-unit.target: You can specify which one to use on each request to get version-specific behaviors, but as a best practice, use the same version throughout your code.

trans-unit.source: The recommended version is 2014-07-31-Preview for general use.
trans-unit.target: The recommended version is 2014-07-31-Preview for general use.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, use 2014-10-20-Preview to evaluate experimental features, such as support for language analyzers expressed through the analyzer index attribute.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, use 2014-10-20-Preview to evaluate experimental features, such as support for language analyzers expressed through the analyzer index attribute.

trans-unit.source: Request Headers
trans-unit.target: Request Headers

trans-unit.source: The following list describes the required and optional request headers.
trans-unit.target: The following list describes the required and optional request headers.

trans-unit.source: Content-Type: Required.
trans-unit.target: Content-Type: Required.

trans-unit.source: Set this to application/json
trans-unit.target: Set this to application/json

trans-unit.source: api-key: Required.
trans-unit.target: api-key: Required.

trans-unit.source: The api-key is used to
trans-unit.target: The api-key is used to

trans-unit.source: authenticate the request to your Search service.
trans-unit.target: authenticate the request to your Search service.

trans-unit.source: It is a string value, unique to your service.
trans-unit.target: It is a string value, unique to your service.

trans-unit.source: The Create Index request must include an api-key header set to your admin key (as opposed to a query key).
trans-unit.target: The Create Index request must include an api-key header set to your admin key (as opposed to a query key).

trans-unit.source: You will also need the service name to construct the request URL.
trans-unit.target: You will also need the service name to construct the request URL.

trans-unit.source: You can get both the service name and api-key from your service dashboard in the Azure Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: You can get both the service name and api-key from your service dashboard in the Azure Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Create an Azure Search service in the portal</linkText><title></title> for page navigation help.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Create an Azure Search service in the portal</linkText><title></title> for page navigation help.

trans-unit.source: Request Body Syntax
trans-unit.target: Request Body Syntax

trans-unit.source: The body of the request contains a schema definition, which includes the list of data fields within documents that will be fed into this index, data types, attributes, as well as an optional list of scoring profiles that are used to score matching documents at query time.
trans-unit.target: The body of the request contains a schema definition, which includes the list of data fields within documents that will be fed into this index, data types, attributes, as well as an optional list of scoring profiles that are used to score matching documents at query time.

trans-unit.source: Note that for a POST request, you must specify the index name in the request body.
trans-unit.target: Note that for a POST request, you must specify the index name in the request body.

trans-unit.source: There can only be one key field in the index.
trans-unit.target: There can only be one key field in the index.

trans-unit.source: It has to be a string field.
trans-unit.target: It has to be a string field.

trans-unit.source: This field represents the unique identifier for each document stored within the index.
trans-unit.target: This field represents the unique identifier for each document stored within the index.

trans-unit.source: The syntax for structuring the request payload is as follows.
trans-unit.target: The syntax for structuring the request payload is as follows.

trans-unit.source: A sample request is provided further on in this topic.
trans-unit.target: A sample request is provided further on in this topic.

trans-unit.source: Note: Data type Edm.Int64 is supported starting with API version 2014-10-20-Preview.
trans-unit.target: Note: Data type Edm.Int64 is supported starting with API version 2014-10-20-Preview.

trans-unit.source: Index Attributes
trans-unit.target: Index Attributes

trans-unit.source: The following attributes can be set when creating an index.
trans-unit.target: The following attributes can be set when creating an index.

trans-unit.source: For details about scoring and scoring profiles, see <linkText>Add scoring profiles to a search index</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For details about scoring and scoring profiles, see <linkText>Add scoring profiles to a search index</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: name - Sets the name of the field.
trans-unit.target: name - Sets the name of the field.

trans-unit.source: type - Sets the data type for the field.
trans-unit.target: type - Sets the data type for the field.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Supported Data Types</linkText><title></title> for a list of supported types.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Supported Data Types</linkText><title></title> for a list of supported types.

trans-unit.source: searchable - Marks the field as full-text search-able.
trans-unit.target: searchable - Marks the field as full-text search-able.

trans-unit.source: This means it will undergo analysis such as word-breaking during indexing.
trans-unit.target: This means it will undergo analysis such as word-breaking during indexing.

trans-unit.source: If you set a searchable field to a value like "sunny day", internally it will be split into the individual tokens "sunny" and "day".
trans-unit.target: If you set a searchable field to a value like "sunny day", internally it will be split into the individual tokens "sunny" and "day".

trans-unit.source: This enables full-text searches for these terms.
trans-unit.target: This enables full-text searches for these terms.

trans-unit.source: Fields of type Edm.String or Collection(Edm.String) are searchable by default.
trans-unit.target: Fields of type Edm.String or Collection(Edm.String) are searchable by default.

trans-unit.source: Fields of other types cannot be searchable.
trans-unit.target: Fields of other types cannot be searchable.

trans-unit.source: Note: searchable fields consume extra space in your index since Azure Search will store an additional tokenized version of the field value for full-text searches.
trans-unit.target: Note: searchable fields consume extra space in your index since Azure Search will store an additional tokenized version of the field value for full-text searches.

trans-unit.source: If you want to save space in your index and you don't need a field to be included in searches, set searchable to false.
trans-unit.target: If you want to save space in your index and you don't need a field to be included in searches, set searchable to false.

trans-unit.source: filterable - Allows the field to be referenced in $filter queries.
trans-unit.target: filterable - Allows the field to be referenced in $filter queries.

trans-unit.source: filterable differs from searchable in how strings are handled.
trans-unit.target: filterable differs from searchable in how strings are handled.

trans-unit.source: Fields of type Edm.String or Collection(Edm.String) that are filterable do not undergo word-breaking, so comparisons are for exact matches only.
trans-unit.target: Fields of type Edm.String or Collection(Edm.String) that are filterable do not undergo word-breaking, so comparisons are for exact matches only.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you set such a field f to "sunny day", $filter=f eq 'sunny' will find no matches, but $filter=f eq 'sunny day' will.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you set such a field f to "sunny day", $filter=f eq 'sunny' will find no matches, but $filter=f eq 'sunny day' will.

trans-unit.source: All fields are filterable by default.
trans-unit.target: All fields are filterable by default.

trans-unit.source: sortable - By default the system sorts results by score, but in many experiences users will want to sort by fields in the documents.
trans-unit.target: sortable - By default the system sorts results by score, but in many experiences users will want to sort by fields in the documents.

trans-unit.source: Fields of type Collection(Edm.String) cannot be sortable.
trans-unit.target: Fields of type Collection(Edm.String) cannot be sortable.

trans-unit.source: All other fields are sortable by default.
trans-unit.target: All other fields are sortable by default.

trans-unit.source: facetable- Typically used in a presentation of search results that includes hit count by category (for example, search for digital cameras and see hits by brand, by megapixels, by price, etc.).
trans-unit.target: facetable- Typically used in a presentation of search results that includes hit count by category (for example, search for digital cameras and see hits by brand, by megapixels, by price, etc.).

trans-unit.source: This option cannot be used with fields of type Edm.GeographyPoint.
trans-unit.target: This option cannot be used with fields of type Edm.GeographyPoint.

trans-unit.source: All other fields are facetable by default.
trans-unit.target: All other fields are facetable by default.

trans-unit.source: Note: Fields of type Edm.String that are filterable, sortable, or facetable can be at most 32KB in length.
trans-unit.target: Note: Fields of type Edm.String that are filterable, sortable, or facetable can be at most 32KB in length.

trans-unit.source: This is because such fields are treated as a single search term, and the maximum length of a term in Azure Search is 32KB.
trans-unit.target: This is because such fields are treated as a single search term, and the maximum length of a term in Azure Search is 32KB.

trans-unit.source: If you need to store more text than this in a single string field, you will need to explicitly set filterable, sortable, and facetable to false in your index definition.
trans-unit.target: If you need to store more text than this in a single string field, you will need to explicitly set filterable, sortable, and facetable to false in your index definition.

trans-unit.source: suggestions - Sets whether the field can be used for auto-complete for type ahead.
trans-unit.target: suggestions - Sets whether the field can be used for auto-complete for type ahead.

trans-unit.source: This can only be set for fields of type Edm.String or Collection(Edm.String).
trans-unit.target: This can only be set for fields of type Edm.String or Collection(Edm.String).

trans-unit.source: suggestions is false by default since it requires extra space in your index.
trans-unit.target: suggestions is false by default since it requires extra space in your index.

trans-unit.source: Note: If a field has none of the above attributes set to true (searchable, filterable, sortable, facetable, or suggestions) the field is effectively excluded from the inverted index.
trans-unit.target: Note: If a field has none of the above attributes set to true (searchable, filterable, sortable, facetable, or suggestions) the field is effectively excluded from the inverted index.

trans-unit.source: This option is useful for fields that are not used in queries, but are needed in search results.
trans-unit.target: This option is useful for fields that are not used in queries, but are needed in search results.

trans-unit.source: Excluding such fields from the index improves performance.
trans-unit.target: Excluding such fields from the index improves performance.

trans-unit.source: key - Marks the field as containing unique identifiers for documents within the index.
trans-unit.target: key - Marks the field as containing unique identifiers for documents within the index.

trans-unit.source: Exactly one field must be chosen as the key field and it must be of type Edm.String.
trans-unit.target: Exactly one field must be chosen as the key field and it must be of type Edm.String.

trans-unit.source: Key fields can be used to look up documents directly via the <linkText>Lookup API</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Key fields can be used to look up documents directly via the <linkText>Lookup API</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: retrievable - Sets whether the field can be returned in a search result.
trans-unit.target: retrievable - Sets whether the field can be returned in a search result.

trans-unit.source: CORS Options
trans-unit.target: CORS Options

trans-unit.source: Client-side Javascript cannot call any APIs by default since the browser will prevent all cross-origin requests.
trans-unit.target: Client-side Javascript cannot call any APIs by default since the browser will prevent all cross-origin requests.

trans-unit.source: Enable CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) by setting the corsOptions attribute to allow cross-origin queries to your index.
trans-unit.target: Enable CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) by setting the corsOptions attribute to allow cross-origin queries to your index.

trans-unit.source: Note that only query APIs support CORS for security reasons.
trans-unit.target: Note that only query APIs support CORS for security reasons.

trans-unit.source: The following options can be set for CORS:
trans-unit.target: The following options can be set for CORS:

trans-unit.source: allowedOrigins (required): This is a list of origins that will be granted access to your index.
trans-unit.target: allowedOrigins (required): This is a list of origins that will be granted access to your index.

trans-unit.source: This means that any Javascript code served from those origins will be allowed to query your index (assuming it provides the correct API key).
trans-unit.target: This means that any Javascript code served from those origins will be allowed to query your index (assuming it provides the correct API key).

trans-unit.source: Each origin is typically of the form protocol://fully-qualified-domain-name:port although the port is often omitted.
trans-unit.target: Each origin is typically of the form protocol://fully-qualified-domain-name:port although the port is often omitted.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>this article</linkText><title></title> for more details.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>this article</linkText><title></title> for more details.

trans-unit.source: If you want to allow access to all origins, include * as a single item in the allowedOrigins array.
trans-unit.target: If you want to allow access to all origins, include * as a single item in the allowedOrigins array.

trans-unit.source: Note that this is not recommended practice for production search services. However, it may be useful for development or debugging purposes.
trans-unit.target: Note that this is not recommended practice for production search services. However, it may be useful for development or debugging purposes.

trans-unit.source: maxAgeInSeconds (optional): Browsers use this value to determine the duration (in seconds) to cache CORS preflight responses.
trans-unit.target: maxAgeInSeconds (optional): Browsers use this value to determine the duration (in seconds) to cache CORS preflight responses.

trans-unit.source: This must be a non-negative integer.
trans-unit.target: This must be a non-negative integer.

trans-unit.source: The larger this value is, the better performance will be, but the longer it will take for CORS policy changes to take effect.
trans-unit.target: The larger this value is, the better performance will be, but the longer it will take for CORS policy changes to take effect.

trans-unit.source: If it is not set, a default duration of 5 minutes will be used.
trans-unit.target: If it is not set, a default duration of 5 minutes will be used.

trans-unit.target: In Azure Search, an index is stored in the cloud and populated using JSON documents that you upload to the service.

trans-unit.source: All the documents that you upload comprise the corpus of your search data.
trans-unit.target: All the documents that you upload comprise the corpus of your search data.

trans-unit.source: Documents contain fields, some of which are tokenized into search terms as they are uploaded.
trans-unit.target: Documents contain fields, some of which are tokenized into search terms as they are uploaded.

trans-unit.source: The /docs URL segment in the Azure Search API represents the collection of documents in an index.
trans-unit.target: The /docs URL segment in the Azure Search API represents the collection of documents in an index.

trans-unit.source: All operations performed on the collection such as uploading, merging, deleting, or querying documents take place in the context of a single index, so the URLs for these operations will always start with /indexes/[index name]/docs for a given index name.
trans-unit.target: All operations performed on the collection such as uploading, merging, deleting, or querying documents take place in the context of a single index, so the URLs for these operations will always start with /indexes/[index name]/docs for a given index name.

trans-unit.source: Your application code must generate JSON documents to upload to Azure Search.
trans-unit.target: Your application code must generate JSON documents to upload to Azure Search.

trans-unit.source: Typically, indexes are populated from a single dataset that you provide.
trans-unit.target: Typically, indexes are populated from a single dataset that you provide.

trans-unit.source: You should plan on having one document for each item that you want to search.
trans-unit.target: You should plan on having one document for each item that you want to search.

trans-unit.source: A movie rental application might have one document per movie, a storefront application might have one document per SKU, an online courseware application might have one document per course, a research firm might have one document for each academic paper in their repository, and so on.
trans-unit.target: A movie rental application might have one document per movie, a storefront application might have one document per SKU, an online courseware application might have one document per course, a research firm might have one document for each academic paper in their repository, and so on.

trans-unit.source: Documents consist of one or more fields.
trans-unit.target: Documents consist of one or more fields.

trans-unit.source: Fields can contain text that is tokenized by Azure Search into search terms, as well as non-tokenized or non-text values that can be used in filters or scoring profiles.
trans-unit.target: Fields can contain text that is tokenized by Azure Search into search terms, as well as non-tokenized or non-text values that can be used in filters or scoring profiles.

trans-unit.source: The names, data types, and search features supported for each field are determined by the index schema.
trans-unit.target: The names, data types, and search features supported for each field are determined by the index schema.

trans-unit.source: One of the fields in each index schema must be designated as an ID, and each document must have a value for the ID field that uniquely identifies that document in the index.
trans-unit.target: One of the fields in each index schema must be designated as an ID, and each document must have a value for the ID field that uniquely identifies that document in the index.

trans-unit.source: All other document fields are optional and will default to a null value if left unspecified.
trans-unit.target: All other document fields are optional and will default to a null value if left unspecified.

trans-unit.source: Note that null values do not take up space in the search index.
trans-unit.target: Note that null values do not take up space in the search index.

trans-unit.source: Before you can upload documents, you must have already created the index on the service.
trans-unit.target: Before you can upload documents, you must have already created the index on the service.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Create Index</linkText><title></title> for details about this first step.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Create Index</linkText><title></title> for details about this first step.

trans-unit.source: Note: This version of the API provides full-text search in English only.
trans-unit.target: Note: This version of the API provides full-text search in English only.

trans-unit.source: You can upload, merge, merge-or-upload or delete documents from a specified index using HTTP POST.
trans-unit.target: You can upload, merge, merge-or-upload or delete documents from a specified index using HTTP POST.

trans-unit.source: For large numbers of updates, batching of documents (up to 1000 documents per batch or about 16 MB per batch) is recommended.
trans-unit.target: For large numbers of updates, batching of documents (up to 1000 documents per batch or about 16 MB per batch) is recommended.

trans-unit.source: Request
trans-unit.target: Request

trans-unit.source: HTTPS is required for all service requests.
trans-unit.target: HTTPS is required for all service requests.

trans-unit.source: You can upload, merge, merge-or-upload or delete documents from a specified index using HTTP POST.
trans-unit.target: You can upload, merge, merge-or-upload or delete documents from a specified index using HTTP POST.

trans-unit.source: The request URI includes [index name], specifying which index to post documents.
trans-unit.target: The request URI includes [index name], specifying which index to post documents.

trans-unit.source: You can only post documents to one index at a time.
trans-unit.target: You can only post documents to one index at a time.

trans-unit.source: The api-version parameter is required.
trans-unit.target: The api-version parameter is required.

trans-unit.source: Valid values include 2014-07-31-Preview or 2014-10-20-Preview.
trans-unit.target: Valid values include 2014-07-31-Preview or 2014-10-20-Preview.

trans-unit.source: You can specify which one to use on each request to get version-specific behaviors, but as a best practice, use the same version throughout your code.
trans-unit.target: You can specify which one to use on each request to get version-specific behaviors, but as a best practice, use the same version throughout your code.

trans-unit.source: The recommended version is 2014-07-31-Preview for general use.
trans-unit.target: The recommended version is 2014-07-31-Preview for general use.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, use 2014-10-20-Preview to evaluate experimental features.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, use 2014-10-20-Preview to evaluate experimental features.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Search Service Versioning</linkText><title></title> for details.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Search Service Versioning</linkText><title></title> for details.

trans-unit.source: Request Headers
trans-unit.target: Request Headers

trans-unit.source: The following list describes the required and optional request headers.
trans-unit.target: The following list describes the required and optional request headers.

trans-unit.source: Content-Type: Required.
trans-unit.target: Content-Type: Required.

trans-unit.source: Set this to application/json
trans-unit.target: Set this to application/json

trans-unit.source: api-key: Required.
trans-unit.target: api-key: Required.

trans-unit.source: The api-key is used to authenticate the request to your Search service.
trans-unit.target: The api-key is used to authenticate the request to your Search service.

trans-unit.source: It is a string value, unique to your service.
trans-unit.target: It is a string value, unique to your service.

trans-unit.source: The Add Documents request must include an api-key header set to your admin key (as opposed to a query key).
trans-unit.target: The Add Documents request must include an api-key header set to your admin key (as opposed to a query key).

trans-unit.source: You will also need the service name to construct the request URL.
trans-unit.target: You will also need the service name to construct the request URL.

trans-unit.source: You can get the service name and api-key from your service dashboard in the Azure Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: You can get the service name and api-key from your service dashboard in the Azure Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Create an Azure Search service in the portal</linkText><title></title> for page navigation help.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Create an Azure Search service in the portal</linkText><title></title> for page navigation help.

trans-unit.source: Request Body
trans-unit.target: Request Body

trans-unit.source: The body of the request contains one or more documents to be indexed.
trans-unit.target: The body of the request contains one or more documents to be indexed.

trans-unit.source: Documents are identified by a unique key.
trans-unit.target: Documents are identified by a unique key.

trans-unit.source: Each document is associated with an action: upload, merge, mergeOrUpload or delete.
trans-unit.target: Each document is associated with an action: upload, merge, mergeOrUpload or delete.

trans-unit.source: Upload requests must include the document data as a set of key/value pairs.
trans-unit.target: Upload requests must include the document data as a set of key/value pairs.

trans-unit.source: Document Actions
trans-unit.target: Document Actions

trans-unit.source: upload: An upload action is similar to an "upsert" where the document will be inserted if it is new and updated/replaced if it exists.
trans-unit.target: upload: An upload action is similar to an "upsert" where the document will be inserted if it is new and updated/replaced if it exists.

trans-unit.source: Note that all fields are replaced in the update case.
trans-unit.target: Note that all fields are replaced in the update case.

trans-unit.source: merge: Merge updates an existing document with the specified fields.
trans-unit.target: merge: Merge updates an existing document with the specified fields.

trans-unit.source: If the document doesn't exist, the merge will fail.
trans-unit.target: If the document doesn't exist, the merge will fail.

trans-unit.source: Any field you specify in a merge will replace the existing field in the document.
trans-unit.target: Any field you specify in a merge will replace the existing field in the document.

trans-unit.source: This includes fields of type Collection(Edm.String).
trans-unit.target: This includes fields of type Collection(Edm.String).

trans-unit.source: For example, if the document contains a field "tags" with value ["budget"] and you execute a merge with value ["economy", "pool"] for "tags", the final value of the "tags" field will be ["economy", "pool"].
trans-unit.target: For example, if the document contains a field "tags" with value ["budget"] and you execute a merge with value ["economy", "pool"] for "tags", the final value of the "tags" field will be ["economy", "pool"].

trans-unit.source: It will not be ["budget", "economy", "pool"].
trans-unit.target: It will not be ["budget", "economy", "pool"].

trans-unit.source: mergeOrUpload: behaves like merge if a document with the given key already exists in the index.
trans-unit.target: mergeOrUpload: behaves like merge if a document with the given key already exists in the index.

trans-unit.source: If the document does not exist it behaves like upload with a new document.
trans-unit.target: If the document does not exist it behaves like upload with a new document.

trans-unit.source: delete: Delete removes the specified document from the index.
trans-unit.target: delete: Delete removes the specified document from the index.

trans-unit.source: Note that you can specify only the key field value in a delete operation.
trans-unit.target: Note that you can specify only the key field value in a delete operation.

trans-unit.source: Attempting to specify other fields will result in an HTTP 400 error.
trans-unit.target: Attempting to specify other fields will result in an HTTP 400 error.

trans-unit.source: If you want to remove an individual field from a document, use merge instead and simply set the field explicitly to null.
trans-unit.target: If you want to remove an individual field from a document, use merge instead and simply set the field explicitly to null.

trans-unit.source: Response
trans-unit.target: Response

trans-unit.source: Status code: 200 OK is returned for a successful response, meaning that all items have been successfully indexed (as indicated by the 'status' field set to true for all items):
trans-unit.target: Status code: 200 OK is returned for a successful response, meaning that all items have been successfully indexed (as indicated by the 'status' field set to true for all items):

trans-unit.source: Status code: 207 is returned when at least one item was not successfully indexed (as indicated by the 'status' field set to false for items that have not been indexed):
trans-unit.target: Status code: 207 is returned when at least one item was not successfully indexed (as indicated by the 'status' field set to false for items that have not been indexed):

trans-unit.source: The errorMessage property will indicate the reason for the indexing error if possible.
trans-unit.target: The errorMessage property will indicate the reason for the indexing error if possible.

trans-unit.source: Note: If your client code frequently encounters a 207 response, one possible reason is that the system is under load.
trans-unit.target: Note: If your client code frequently encounters a 207 response, one possible reason is that the system is under load.

trans-unit.source: You can confirm this by checking the errorMessage property.
trans-unit.target: You can confirm this by checking the errorMessage property.

trans-unit.source: If this is the case, we recommend *throttling indexing requests*.
trans-unit.target: If this is the case, we recommend *throttling indexing requests*.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, if indexing traffic doesn't subside, the system could start rejecting all requests with 503 errors.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, if indexing traffic doesn't subside, the system could start rejecting all requests with 503 errors.

trans-unit.source: Status code: 429 indicates that you have exceeded your quota on the number of documents per index.
trans-unit.target: Status code: 429 indicates that you have exceeded your quota on the number of documents per index.

trans-unit.source: You must either create a new index or upgrade for higher capacity limits.
trans-unit.target: You must either create a new index or upgrade for higher capacity limits.

trans-unit.source: Example:
trans-unit.target: Example:

trans-unit.source: A Search operation is issued as a GET request and specifies query parameters that give the criteria for selecting matching documents.
trans-unit.target: A Search operation is issued as a GET request and specifies query parameters that give the criteria for selecting matching documents.

trans-unit.source: Request
trans-unit.target: Request

trans-unit.source: HTTPS is required for service requests.
trans-unit.target: HTTPS is required for service requests.

trans-unit.source: The Search request can be constructed using the GET method.
trans-unit.target: The Search request can be constructed using the GET method.

trans-unit.source: The request URI specifies which index to query, for all documents that match the query parameters.
trans-unit.target: The request URI specifies which index to query, for all documents that match the query parameters.

trans-unit.source: Query Parameters
trans-unit.target: Query Parameters

trans-unit.source: search=[string] (optional) - the text to search for.
trans-unit.target: search=[string] (optional) - the text to search for.

trans-unit.source: All searchable fields are searched by default unless searchFields is specified.
trans-unit.target: All searchable fields are searched by default unless searchFields is specified.

trans-unit.source: When searching searchable fields, the search text itself is tokenized, so multiple terms can be separated by white space (for example: search=hello world).
trans-unit.target: When searching searchable fields, the search text itself is tokenized, so multiple terms can be separated by white space (for example: search=hello world).

trans-unit.source: To match any term, use * (this can be useful for boolean filter queries).
trans-unit.target: To match any term, use * (this can be useful for boolean filter queries).

trans-unit.source: Omitting this parameter has the same effect as setting it to *.
trans-unit.target: Omitting this parameter has the same effect as setting it to *.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Simple Query Syntax</linkText><title></title> for specifics on the search syntax.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Simple Query Syntax</linkText><title></title> for specifics on the search syntax.

trans-unit.source: Note: The results can sometimes be surprising when querying over searchable fields.
trans-unit.target: Note: The results can sometimes be surprising when querying over searchable fields.

trans-unit.source: The tokenizer includes logic to handle cases common to English text like apostrophes, commas in numbers, etc. For example, search=123,456 will match a single term 123,456 rather than the individual terms 123 and 456, since commas are used as thousand-separators for large numbers in English.
trans-unit.target: The tokenizer includes logic to handle cases common to English text like apostrophes, commas in numbers, etc. For example, search=123,456 will match a single term 123,456 rather than the individual terms 123 and 456, since commas are used as thousand-separators for large numbers in English.

trans-unit.source: For this reason, we recommend using white space rather than punctuation to separate terms in the search parameter.
trans-unit.target: For this reason, we recommend using white space rather than punctuation to separate terms in the search parameter.

trans-unit.source: searchMode=any|all (optional, defaults to any) - whether any or all of the search terms must be matched in order to count the document as a match.
trans-unit.target: searchMode=any|all (optional, defaults to any) - whether any or all of the search terms must be matched in order to count the document as a match.

trans-unit.source: searchFields=[string] (optional) - the list of comma-separated field names to search for the specified text.
trans-unit.target: searchFields=[string] (optional) - the list of comma-separated field names to search for the specified text.

trans-unit.source: Target fields must be marked as searchable.
trans-unit.target: Target fields must be marked as searchable.

trans-unit.source: $skip=# (optional) - the # of search results to skip; Cannot be greater than 100,000.
trans-unit.target: $skip=# (optional) - the # of search results to skip; Cannot be greater than 100,000.

trans-unit.source: If you need to scan documents in sequence but cannot use $skip due to this limitation, consider using $orderby on a totally-ordered key and $filter with a range query instead.
trans-unit.target: If you need to scan documents in sequence but cannot use $skip due to this limitation, consider using $orderby on a totally-ordered key and $filter with a range query instead.

trans-unit.source: $top=# (optional) - the # of search results to retrieve.
trans-unit.target: $top=# (optional) - the # of search results to retrieve.

trans-unit.source: This defaults to 50.
trans-unit.target: This defaults to 50.

trans-unit.source: If you specify a value greater than 1000 and there are more than 1000 results, only the first 1000 results will be returned, along with a link to the next page of results (see @odata.nextLink in the example below).
trans-unit.target: If you specify a value greater than 1000 and there are more than 1000 results, only the first 1000 results will be returned, along with a link to the next page of results (see @odata.nextLink in the example below).

trans-unit.source: $count=true|false (optional, defaults to false) - whether to fetch the total count of results.
trans-unit.target: $count=true|false (optional, defaults to false) - whether to fetch the total count of results.

trans-unit.source: Setting this value to true may have a performance impact.
trans-unit.target: Setting this value to true may have a performance impact.

trans-unit.source: Note that the count returned is an approximation.
trans-unit.target: Note that the count returned is an approximation.

trans-unit.source: $orderby=[string] (optional) - a list of comma-separated expressions to sort the results by.
trans-unit.target: $orderby=[string] (optional) - a list of comma-separated expressions to sort the results by.

trans-unit.source: Each expression can be either a field name or a call to the geo.distance() function.
trans-unit.target: Each expression can be either a field name or a call to the geo.distance() function.

trans-unit.source: Each expression can be followed by asc to indicated ascending, and desc to indicate descending.
trans-unit.target: Each expression can be followed by asc to indicated ascending, and desc to indicate descending.

trans-unit.source: The default is ascending order.
trans-unit.target: The default is ascending order.

trans-unit.source: Ties will be broken by the match scores of documents.
trans-unit.target: Ties will be broken by the match scores of documents.

trans-unit.source: If no $orderby is specified, the default sort order is descending by document match score.
trans-unit.target: If no $orderby is specified, the default sort order is descending by document match score.

trans-unit.source: There is a limit of 32 clauses for $orderby.
trans-unit.target: There is a limit of 32 clauses for $orderby.

trans-unit.source: $select=[string] (optional) - a list of comma-separated fields to retrieve.
trans-unit.target: $select=[string] (optional) - a list of comma-separated fields to retrieve.

trans-unit.source: If unspecified, all fields marked as retrievable in the schema are included.
trans-unit.target: If unspecified, all fields marked as retrievable in the schema are included.

trans-unit.source: You can also explicitly request all fields by setting this parameter to *.
trans-unit.target: You can also explicitly request all fields by setting this parameter to *.

trans-unit.source: facet=[string] (zero or more) - a field to facet by.
trans-unit.target: facet=[string] (zero or more) - a field to facet by.

trans-unit.source: Optionally the string may contain parameters to customize the faceting expressed as comma-separated name:value pairs.
trans-unit.target: Optionally the string may contain parameters to customize the faceting expressed as comma-separated name:value pairs.

trans-unit.source: Valid parameters are:
trans-unit.target: Valid parameters are:

trans-unit.source: count (max # of facet terms; default is 10).
trans-unit.target: count (max # of facet terms; default is 10).

trans-unit.source: There is no maximum, but higher values incur a corresponding performance penalty, especially if the faceted field contains a large number of unique terms.
trans-unit.target: There is no maximum, but higher values incur a corresponding performance penalty, especially if the faceted field contains a large number of unique terms.

trans-unit.source: For example: facet=category,count:5 gets the top five categories in facet results.
trans-unit.target: For example: facet=category,count:5 gets the top five categories in facet results.

trans-unit.source: Note: If the count parameter is less than the number of unique terms, the results may not be accurate.
trans-unit.target: Note: If the count parameter is less than the number of unique terms, the results may not be accurate.

trans-unit.source: This is due to the way faceting queries are distributed across shards.
trans-unit.target: This is due to the way faceting queries are distributed across shards.

trans-unit.source: Increasing count generally increases the accuracy of the term counts, but at a performance cost.
trans-unit.target: Increasing count generally increases the accuracy of the term counts, but at a performance cost.

trans-unit.source: sort (one of count to sort descending by count, -count to sort ascending by count, value to sort ascending by value, or -value to sort descending by value)
trans-unit.target: sort (one of count to sort descending by count, -count to sort ascending by count, value to sort ascending by value, or -value to sort descending by value)

trans-unit.source: For example: facet=category,count:3,sort:count gets the top three categories in facet results in descending order by the number of documents with each city name.
trans-unit.target: For example: facet=category,count:3,sort:count gets the top three categories in facet results in descending order by the number of documents with each city name.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the top three categories are Budget, Motel, and Luxury, and Budget has 5 hits, Motel has 6, and Luxury has 4, then the buckets will be in the order Motel, Budget, Luxury.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the top three categories are Budget, Motel, and Luxury, and Budget has 5 hits, Motel has 6, and Luxury has 4, then the buckets will be in the order Motel, Budget, Luxury.

trans-unit.source: For example: facet=rating,sort:-value produces buckets for all possible ratings, in descending order by value.
trans-unit.target: For example: facet=rating,sort:-value produces buckets for all possible ratings, in descending order by value.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the ratings are from 1 to 5, the buckets will be ordered 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, irrespective of how many documents match each rating.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the ratings are from 1 to 5, the buckets will be ordered 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, irrespective of how many documents match each rating.

trans-unit.source: values (pipe-delimited numeric or Edm.DateTimeOffset values specifying a dynamic set of facet entry values)
trans-unit.target: values (pipe-delimited numeric or Edm.DateTimeOffset values specifying a dynamic set of facet entry values)

trans-unit.source: For example: facet=baseRate,values:10|20 produces three buckets: One for base rate 0 up to but not including 10, one for 10 up to but not including 20, and one for 20 or higher.
trans-unit.target: For example: facet=baseRate,values:10|20 produces three buckets: One for base rate 0 up to but not including 10, one for 10 up to but not including 20, and one for 20 or higher.

trans-unit.source: For example: facet=lastRenovationDate,values:2010-02-01T00:00:00Z produces two buckets: One for hotels renovated before February 2010, and one for hotels renovated February 1st, 2010 or later.
trans-unit.target: For example: facet=lastRenovationDate,values:2010-02-01T00:00:00Z produces two buckets: One for hotels renovated before February 2010, and one for hotels renovated February 1st, 2010 or later.

trans-unit.source: interval (integer interval greater than 0 for numbers, or minute, hour, day, week, month, quarter, year for date time values)
trans-unit.target: interval (integer interval greater than 0 for numbers, or minute, hour, day, week, month, quarter, year for date time values)

trans-unit.source: For example: facet=baseRate,interval:100 produces buckets based on base rate ranges of size 100.
trans-unit.target: For example: facet=baseRate,interval:100 produces buckets based on base rate ranges of size 100.

trans-unit.source: For example, if base rates are all between $60 and $600, there will be buckets for 0-100, 100-200, 200-300, 300-400, 400-500, and 500-600.
trans-unit.target: For example, if base rates are all between $60 and $600, there will be buckets for 0-100, 100-200, 200-300, 300-400, 400-500, and 500-600.

trans-unit.source: For example: facet=lastRenovationDate,interval:year produces one bucket for each year when hotels were renovated.
trans-unit.target: For example: facet=lastRenovationDate,interval:year produces one bucket for each year when hotels were renovated.

trans-unit.source: Note: count and sort can be combined in the same facet specification, but they cannot be combined with interval or values, and interval and values cannot be combined together.
trans-unit.target: Note: count and sort can be combined in the same facet specification, but they cannot be combined with interval or values, and interval and values cannot be combined together.

trans-unit.source: $filter=[string] (optional) - a structured search expression in standard OData syntax.
trans-unit.target: $filter=[string] (optional) - a structured search expression in standard OData syntax.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>OData Expression Syntax</linkText><title></title> for details on the subset of the OData expression grammar that Azure Search supports.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>OData Expression Syntax</linkText><title></title> for details on the subset of the OData expression grammar that Azure Search supports.

trans-unit.source: highlight=[string] (optional) - a set of comma-separated field names used for hit highlights.
trans-unit.target: highlight=[string] (optional) - a set of comma-separated field names used for hit highlights.

trans-unit.source: Only searchable fields can be used for hit highlighting.
trans-unit.target: Only searchable fields can be used for hit highlighting.

trans-unit.source: scoringProfile=[string] (optional) - the name of a scoring profile to evaluate match scores for matching documents in order to sort the results.
trans-unit.target: scoringProfile=[string] (optional) - the name of a scoring profile to evaluate match scores for matching documents in order to sort the results.

trans-unit.source: scoringParameter=[string] (zero or more) - indicates the value for each parameter defined in a scoring function (for example, referencePointParameter) using the format name:value. For example, if the scoring profile defines a function with a parameter called "mylocation" the query string option would be &scoringParameter=mylocation:-122.2,44.8
trans-unit.target: scoringParameter=[string] (zero or more) - indicates the value for each parameter defined in a scoring function (for example, referencePointParameter) using the format name:value. For example, if the scoring profile defines a function with a parameter called "mylocation" the query string option would be &scoringParameter=mylocation:-122.2,44.8

trans-unit.source: api-version=[string] (required).
trans-unit.target: api-version=[string] (required).

trans-unit.source: Valid values include 2014-07-31-Preview or 2014-10-20-Preview.
trans-unit.target: Valid values include 2014-07-31-Preview or 2014-10-20-Preview.

trans-unit.source: You can specify which one to use on each request to get version-specific behaviors, but as a best practice, use the same version throughout your code.
trans-unit.target: You can specify which one to use on each request to get version-specific behaviors, but as a best practice, use the same version throughout your code.

trans-unit.source: The recommended version is 2014-07-31-Preview for general use.
trans-unit.target: The recommended version is 2014-07-31-Preview for general use.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, use 2014-10-20-Preview to evaluate experimental features.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, use 2014-10-20-Preview to evaluate experimental features.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Search Service Versioning</linkText><title></title> for details.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Search Service Versioning</linkText><title></title> for details.

trans-unit.source: Note: For this operation, the api-version is specified as a query parameter.
trans-unit.target: Note: For this operation, the api-version is specified as a query parameter.

trans-unit.target: Request Headers

trans-unit.source: The following list describes the required and optional request headers.
trans-unit.target: The following list describes the required and optional request headers.

trans-unit.source: api-key: The api-key is used to authenticate the request to your Search service.

trans-unit.source: The Lookup Document operation retrieves a document from Azure Search.
trans-unit.target: The Lookup Document operation retrieves a document from Azure Search.

trans-unit.source: This is useful when a user clicks on a specific search result, and you want to look up specific details about that document.
trans-unit.target: This is useful when a user clicks on a specific search result, and you want to look up specific details about that document.

trans-unit.target: The request URI includes an [index name] and [key], specifying which document to retrieve from which index.

trans-unit.source: You can only get one document at a time.
trans-unit.target: You can only get one document at a time.

trans-unit.source: Use Search to get multiple documents in a single request.

trans-unit.source: The Count Documents operation retrieves a count of the number of documents in a search index.

trans-unit.source: The Suggestions operation retrieves suggestions based on partial search input.
trans-unit.target: The Suggestions operation retrieves suggestions based on partial search input.

trans-unit.source: It's typically used in search boxes to provide type-ahead suggestions as users are entering search terms.
trans-unit.target: It's typically used in search boxes to provide type-ahead suggestions as users are entering search terms.

trans-unit.source: Suggested text may be repeated if multiple candidates match the same search input.
trans-unit.target: Suggested text may be repeated if multiple candidates match the same search input.

trans-unit.source: You can use $select to retrieve other document fields (including the document key) so that you can tell which document is the source for each suggestion.
trans-unit.target: You can use $select to retrieve other document fields (including the document key) so that you can tell which document is the source for each suggestion.

trans-unit.source: Request
trans-unit.target: Request

trans-unit.source: HTTPS is required for service requests.
trans-unit.target: HTTPS is required for service requests.

trans-unit.source: The Suggestions request can be constructed using the GET method.
trans-unit.target: The Suggestions request can be constructed using the GET method.

trans-unit.source: The request URI specifies the name of the index to query.
trans-unit.target: The request URI specifies the name of the index to query.

trans-unit.source: It also includes the partially input search term in the query string.
trans-unit.target: It also includes the partially input search term in the query string.

trans-unit.source: Query Parameters
trans-unit.target: Query Parameters

trans-unit.source: search=[string] - the search text to use to suggest queries.
trans-unit.target: search=[string] - the search text to use to suggest queries.

trans-unit.source: Must be at least 3 characters, and no more than 25 characters.
trans-unit.target: Must be at least 3 characters, and no more than 25 characters.

trans-unit.source: fuzzy=[boolean] (optional, default = false) - when set to true this API will find suggestions even if there's a substituted or missing character in the search text.
trans-unit.target: fuzzy=[boolean] (optional, default = false) - when set to true this API will find suggestions even if there's a substituted or missing character in the search text.

trans-unit.source: While this provides a better experience in some scenarios it comes at a performance cost as fuzzy suggestion searches are slower and consume more resources.
trans-unit.target: While this provides a better experience in some scenarios it comes at a performance cost as fuzzy suggestion searches are slower and consume more resources.

trans-unit.source: searchFields=[string] (optional) - the list of comma-separated field names to search for the specified search text.
trans-unit.target: searchFields=[string] (optional) - the list of comma-separated field names to search for the specified search text.

trans-unit.source: Target fields must be enabled for suggestions.
trans-unit.target: Target fields must be enabled for suggestions.

trans-unit.source: $top=# (optional, default = 5) - the number of suggestions to retrieve.
trans-unit.target: $top=# (optional, default = 5) - the number of suggestions to retrieve.

trans-unit.source: Must be a number between 1 and 10.
trans-unit.target: Must be a number between 1 and 10.

trans-unit.source: $filter=[string] (optional) - an expression that filters the documents considered for suggestions.
trans-unit.target: $filter=[string] (optional) - an expression that filters the documents considered for suggestions.

trans-unit.source: $orderby=[string] (optional) - a list of comma-separated expressions to sort the results by.
trans-unit.target: $orderby=[string] (optional) - a list of comma-separated expressions to sort the results by.

trans-unit.source: Each expression can be either a field name or a call to the geo.distance() function.
trans-unit.target: Each expression can be either a field name or a call to the geo.distance() function.

trans-unit.source: Each expression can be followed by asc to indicated ascending, and desc to indicate descending.
trans-unit.target: Each expression can be followed by asc to indicated ascending, and desc to indicate descending.

trans-unit.source: The default is ascending order.
trans-unit.target: The default is ascending order.

trans-unit.source: There is a limit of 32 clauses for $orderby.
trans-unit.target: There is a limit of 32 clauses for $orderby.

trans-unit.source: $select=[string] (optional) - a list of comma-separated fields to retrieve.
trans-unit.target: $select=[string] (optional) - a list of comma-separated fields to retrieve.

trans-unit.source: If unspecified, only the document key and suggestion text is returned.
trans-unit.target: If unspecified, only the document key and suggestion text is returned.

trans-unit.target: api-version=[string] (required).

trans-unit.source: Valid values include 2014-07-31-Preview or 2014-10-20-Preview.
trans-unit.target: Valid values include 2014-07-31-Preview or 2014-10-20-Preview.
